awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Plastic Ceramics: The Role of Grain Boundaries During Laser Shock Peening
awd_abstract_narration:
NON-TECHNICAL DESCRIPTION: Laser shock peening (LSP) is a new surface engineering method that has been proven to prevent crack growth in several ceramic materials, which are inherently brittle. In particular, success has been found with ceramics suitable for applications in extreme environments (e.g., hypersonic vehicles, gas-turbine engines, and armor). The general applicability of this technique is impeded because the underlying mechanisms are not fully understood. The goal of this project is to identify the role internal interfaces play during LSP to guide future material design, which will extend the applicability of this technique and increase its effectiveness at improving the ceramics’ mechanical performance. The next generation of ceramic engineers are being trained on these methods and approaches to enable the processing and implementation of tough structural ceramics. In addition to the two doctoral students, undergraduate and high school students are being recruited to participate in the project each summer.  

TECHNICAL DETAILS: This research identifies how grain boundary character (macroscopic parameters, thickness, and chemistry) in ceramics affects the propensity to form dislocations and, thus, build compressive residual stresses during LSP. LSP has been adapted to ceramic materials such as silicon carbide and alumina to induce compressive residual stresses that improve their crack resistance. Yet, the fundamental mechanisms and the broad applicability of the technique remain poorly understood. The scientific hypothesis is that LSP will be applicable to materials with higher order complexions – equilibrium grain boundary states with high disorder – to generate shock wave propagations that initiate dislocation formation necessary for building compressive residual stresses near grain boundaries. To test this hypothesis, the effect of LSP is being investigated in various grain boundaries of different character and composition in alpha-phase alumina with complexion engineering. The specific aims are to (1) correlate the extent of compressive residual stress induced by LSP with grain boundary character distributions and grain size and (2) identify individual grain boundary structures associated high dislocation density. Engineering students are learning valuable skills in ceramic processing and electron microscopy characterization.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: BOARD OF REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF NEBRASKA

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
The intrinsic brittleness and low fracture toughness are the significant limitations for most ceramic materials. Laser shock peening (LSP) is a novel surface engineering method that can effectively prevent crack growth in brittle ceramic materials such as alumina, silicon carbide, and silicon nitride. The application of this technology to ceramic industry has been limited by the insufficient understanding of fundamental mechanisms, particularly the role of microstructures, that control the interaction between nanosecond pulsed laser-driven shock waves and ceramics. The goal of this project is to understand these physical mechanisms during LSP to guide the process design, which can improve the mechanical performance and extend the lifetime of structural ceramic parts used in aerospace and energy industries. 

During this project, it has been found that several factors are critical to the response of ceramics to LSP including impurities, material synthesis routes, and temperatures. These findings suggest that the synthesis route and microstructures of ceramics can be optimized to enhance the effects of LSP and thus the resistance to fracture. Additionally, the LSP process can be improved by performing at high temperatures. Higher temperatures may be desirable in brittle ceramics to introduce plastic deformation and dislocations that help prevent fracture. Overall, this research project shows that the LSP process is a viable engineering process for improving the crack resistance of ceramics through the introduction of compressive residual stress and localized plastic deformation near the surface. 

This research has the potential to guide the further development of LSP process and system for applications in energy and aerospace industries. This project has the product of three journal publications and several invited talks at international conferences and has promoted engineering education through training of two graduate students and hosting two high school intern students in summers.

 


Last Modified: 05/31/2024
Modified by: Bai Cui
